text: Solomon son of David solidified his royal authority, for the Lord his God was with him and magnified him greatly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon addressed all Israel, including those who commanded units of a thousand and a hundred, the judges, and all the leaders of all Israel who were heads of families.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon and the entire assembly went to the worship center in Gibeon, for the tent where they met God was located there, which Moses the Lord’s servant had made in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Now David had brought up the ark of God from Kiriath Jearim to the place he had prepared for it, for he had pitched a tent for it in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the bronze altar made by Bezalel son of Uri, son of Hur, was in front of the Lord’s tabernacle. Solomon and the entire assembly prayed to him there.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon went up to the bronze altar before the Lord which was at the meeting tent, and he offered up 1,000 burnt sacrifices.
speaker: Narrator

text: That night God appeared to Solomon and said to him, “Tell me what I should give you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon replied to God, “You demonstrated great loyalty to my father David and have made me king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, Lord God, may your promise to my father David be realized, for you have made me king over a great nation as numerous as the dust of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now give me wisdom and discernment so I can effectively lead this nation. Otherwise no one is able to make judicial decisions for this great nation of yours.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God said to Solomon, “Because you desire this, and did not ask for riches, wealth, and honor, or for vengeance on your enemies, and because you did not ask for long life, but requested wisdom and discernment so you can make judicial decisions for my people over whom I have made you king,
speaker: Narrator

text: you are granted wisdom and discernment. Furthermore I am giving you riches, wealth, and honor surpassing that of any king before or after you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon left the meeting tent at the worship center in Gibeon and went to Jerusalem, where he reigned over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon accumulated chariots and horses. He had 1,400 chariots and 12,000 horses . He kept them in assigned cities and in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king made silver and gold as plentiful in Jerusalem as stones; cedar was as plentiful as sycamore fig trees are in the foothills.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon acquired his horses from Egypt and from Que; the king’s traders purchased them from Que.
speaker: Narrator

text: They paid 600 silver pieces for each chariot from Egypt, and 150 silver pieces for each horse. They also sold chariots and horses to all the kings of the Hittites and to the kings of Syria.
speaker: Narrator

text: (1:18) Solomon ordered a temple to be built to honor the Lord, as well as a royal palace for himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: (2:1) Solomon had 70,000 common laborers and 80,000 stonecutters in the hills, in addition to 3,600 supervisors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon sent a message to King Huram of Tyre: “Help me as you did my father David, when you sent him cedar logs for the construction of his palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, I am ready to build a temple to honor the Lord my God and to dedicate it to him in order to burn fragrant incense before him, to set out the bread that is regularly displayed, and to offer burnt sacrifices each morning and evening, and on Sabbaths, new moon festivals, and at other times appointed by the Lord our God. This is something Israel must do on a permanent basis.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will build a great temple, for our God is greater than all gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of course, who can really build a temple for him, since the sky and the highest heavens cannot contain him? Who am I that I should build him a temple! It will really be only a place to offer sacrifices before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now send me a man who is skilled in working with gold, silver, bronze, and iron, as well as purple-, crimson-, and blue-colored fabrics, and who knows how to engrave. He will work with my skilled craftsmen here in Jerusalem and Judah, whom my father David provided.
speaker: Narrator

text: Send me cedars, evergreens, and algum trees from Lebanon, for I know your servants are adept at cutting down trees in Lebanon. My servants will work with your servants
speaker: Narrator

text: to supply me with large quantities of timber, for I am building a great, magnificent temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, I will pay your servants who cut the timber 20,000 cors of ground wheat, 20,000 cors of barley, 120,000 gallons of wine, and 120,000 gallons of olive oil.”
speaker: Narrator

text: King Huram of Tyre sent this letter to Solomon: “Because the Lord loves his people, he has made you their king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Huram also said, “Worthy of praise is the Lord God of Israel, who made the sky and the earth! He has given King David a wise son who has discernment and insight and will build a temple for the Lord, as well as a royal palace for himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I am sending you Huram Abi, a skilled and capable man,
speaker: Narrator

text: whose mother is a Danite and whose father is a Tyrian. He knows how to work with gold, silver, bronze, iron, stones, and wood, as well as purple, blue, white, and crimson fabrics. He knows how to do all kinds of engraving and understands any design given to him. He will work with your skilled craftsmen and the skilled craftsmen of my lord David your father.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now let my lord send to his servants the wheat, barley, olive oil, and wine he has promised;
speaker: Narrator

text: we will get all the timber you need from Lebanon and bring it in raft-like bundles by sea to Joppa. You can then haul it on up to Jerusalem.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon took a census of all the male resident foreigners in the land of Israel, after the census his father David had taken. There were 153,600 in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: He designated 70,000 as common laborers, 80,000 as stonecutters in the hills, and 3,600 as supervisors to make sure the people completed the work.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon began building the Lord’s temple in Jerusalem on Mount Moriah, where the Lord had appeared to his father David. This was the place that David prepared at the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite.
speaker: Narrator

text: He began building on the second day of the second month of the fourth year of his reign.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon laid the foundation for God’s temple; its length (determined according to the old standard of measure) was 90 feet, and its width 30 feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: The porch in front of the main hall was 30 feet long, corresponding to the width of the temple, and its height was 30 feet. He plated the inside with pure gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: He paneled the main hall with boards made from evergreen trees and plated it with fine gold, decorated with palm trees and chains.
speaker: Narrator

text: He decorated the temple with precious stones; the gold he used came from Parvaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: He overlaid the temple’s rafters, thresholds, walls and doors with gold; he carved decorative cherubim on the walls.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made the Most Holy Place; its length was 30 feet, corresponding to the width of the temple, and its width 30 feet. He plated it with 600 talents of fine gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: The gold nails weighed 50 shekels; he also plated the upper areas with gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the Most Holy Place he made two images of cherubim and plated them with gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: The combined wing span of the cherubim was 30 feet. One of the first cherub’s wings was 7½ long and touched one wall of the temple; its other wing was also 7½ long and touched one of the second cherub’s wings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Likewise one of the second cherub’s wings was 7½ long and touched the other wall of the temple; its other wing was also 7½ long and touched one of the first cherub’s wings.
speaker: Narrator

text: The combined wingspan of these cherubim was 30 feet. They stood upright, facing inward.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made the curtain out of blue, purple, crimson, and white fabrics, and embroidered on it decorative cherubim.
speaker: Narrator

text: In front of the temple he made two pillars which had a combined length of 52½ feet, with each having a plated capital 7½ high.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made ornamental chains and put them on top of the pillars. He also made 100 pomegranate-shaped ornaments and arranged them within the chains.
speaker: Narrator

text: He set up the pillars in front of the temple, one on the right side and the other on the left. He named the one on the right Yakin, and the one on the left Boaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made a bronze altar, 30 feet long, 30 feet wide, and 15 feet high.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also made the big bronze basin called “The Sea.” It measured 15 feet from rim to rim, was circular in shape, and stood 7½ high. Its circumference was 45 feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Images of bulls were under it all the way around, ten every 18 inches all the way around. The bulls were in two rows and had been cast with “The Sea.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Sea” stood on top of twelve bulls. Three faced northward, three westward, three southward, and three eastward. “The Sea” was placed on top of them, and they all faced outward.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was four fingers thick, and its rim was like that of a cup shaped like a lily blossom. It could hold 18,000 gallons.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made ten washing basins; he put five on the south side and five on the north side. In them they rinsed the items used for burnt sacrifices; the priests washed in “The Sea.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He made ten gold lampstands according to specifications and put them in the temple, five on the right and five on the left.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made ten tables and set them in the temple, five on the right and five on the left. He also made 100 gold bowls.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made the courtyard of the priests and the large enclosure and its doors; he plated their doors with bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put “The Sea” on the south side, in the southeast corner.
speaker: Narrator

text: Huram Abi made the pots, shovels, and bowls. He finished all the work on God’s temple he had been assigned by King Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made the two pillars, the two bowl-shaped tops of the pillars, the latticework for the bowl-shaped tops of the two pillars,
speaker: Narrator

text: the 400 pomegranate-shaped ornaments for the latticework of the two pillars (each latticework had two rows of these ornaments at the bowl-shaped top of the pillar),
speaker: Narrator

text: the ten movable stands with their ten basins,
speaker: Narrator

text: the big bronze basin called “The Sea” with its twelve bulls underneath,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the pots, shovels, and meat forks. All the items King Solomon assigned Huram Abi to make for the Lord’s temple were made from polished bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king had them cast in earth foundries in the region of the Jordan between Sukkoth and Zarethan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon made so many of these items they did not weigh the bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon also made these items for God’s temple: the gold altar, the tables on which the Bread of the Presence was kept,
speaker: Narrator

text: the pure gold lampstands and their lamps which burned as specified at the entrance to the inner sanctuary,
speaker: Narrator

text: the pure gold flower-shaped ornaments, lamps, and tongs,
speaker: Narrator

text: the pure gold trimming shears, basins, pans, and censers, and the gold door sockets for the inner sanctuary (the Most Holy Place) and for the doors of the main hall of the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Solomon had finished constructing the Lord’s temple, he put the holy items that belonged to his father David (the silver, gold, and all the other articles) in the treasuries of God’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Solomon convened Israel’s elders—all the leaders of the Israelite tribes and families—in Jerusalem, so they could witness the transferal of the ark of the covenant of the Lord from the City of David (that is, Zion).
speaker: Narrator

text: All the men of Israel assembled before the king during the festival in the seventh month.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all Israel’s elders had arrived, the Levites lifted the ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests and Levites carried the ark, the tent where God appeared to his people, and all the holy items in the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now King Solomon and all the Israelites who had assembled with him went on ahead of the ark and sacrificed more sheep and cattle than could be counted or numbered.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests brought the ark of the covenant of the Lord to its assigned place in the inner sanctuary of the temple, in the Most Holy Place under the wings of the cherubim.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cherubim’s wings extended over the place where the ark sat; the cherubim overshadowed the ark and its poles.
speaker: Narrator

text: The poles were so long their ends extending out from the ark were visible from in front of the inner sanctuary, but they could not be seen from beyond that point. They have remained there to this very day.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was nothing in the ark except the two tablets Moses had placed there in Horeb. (It was there that the Lord made a covenant with the Israelites after he brought them out of the land of Egypt.)
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests left the Holy Place. All the priests who participated had consecrated themselves, no matter which division they represented.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the Levites who were musicians, including Asaph, Heman, Jeduthun, and their sons and relatives, wore linen. They played cymbals and stringed instruments as they stood east of the altar. They were accompanied by 120 priests who blew trumpets.
speaker: Narrator

text: The trumpeters and musicians played together, praising and giving thanks to the Lord. Accompanied by trumpets, cymbals, and other instruments, they loudly praised the Lord, singing: “Certainly he is good; certainly his loyal love endures!” Then a cloud filled the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests could not carry out their duties because of the cloud; the Lord’s splendor filled God’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Solomon said, “The Lord has said that he lives in thick darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: O Lord, I have built a lofty temple for you, a place where you can live permanently.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king turned around and pronounced a blessing over the whole Israelite assembly as they stood there.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “The Lord God of Israel is worthy of praise because he has fulfilled what he promised my father David.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told David, ‘Since the day I brought my people out of the land of Egypt, I have not chosen a city from all the tribes of Israel to build a temple in which to live. Nor did I choose a man as leader of my people Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now I have chosen Jerusalem as a place to live, and I have chosen David to lead my people Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now my father David had a strong desire to build a temple to honor the Lord God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord told my father David, ‘It is right for you to have a strong desire to build a temple to honor me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you will not build the temple; your very own son will build the temple for my honor.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord has kept the promise he made. I have taken my father David’s place and have occupied the throne of Israel, as the Lord promised. I have built this temple for the honor of the Lord God of Israel
speaker: Narrator

text: and set up in it a place for the ark containing the covenant the Lord made with the Israelites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He stood before the altar of the Lord in front of the entire assembly of Israel and spread out his hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon had made a bronze platform and had placed it in the middle of the enclosure. It was 7½ long, 7½ wide, and 4½ feet high. He stood on it and then got down on his knees in front of the entire assembly of Israel. He spread out his hands toward the sky,
speaker: Narrator

text: and prayed: “O Lord God of Israel, there is no god like you in heaven or on earth! You maintain covenantal loyalty to your servants who obey you with sincerity.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have kept your word to your servant, my father David; this very day you have fulfilled what you promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, O Lord God of Israel, keep the promise you made to your servant, my father David, when you said, ‘You will never fail to have a successor ruling before me on the throne of Israel, provided that your descendants watch their step and obey my law as you have done.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, O Lord God of Israel, may the promise you made to your servant David be realized.
speaker: Narrator

text: “God does not really live with humankind on the earth! Look, if the sky and the highest heaven cannot contain you, how much less this temple I have built!
speaker: Narrator

text: But respond favorably to your servant’s prayer and his request for help, O Lord my God. Answer the desperate prayer your servant is presenting to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Night and day may you watch over this temple, the place where you promised you would live. May you answer your servant’s prayer for this place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Respond to the requests of your servant and your people Israel for this place. Hear from your heavenly dwelling place and respond favorably and forgive.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When someone is accused of sinning against his neighbor and the latter pronounces a curse on the alleged offender before your altar in this temple,
speaker: Narrator

text: listen from heaven and make a just decision about your servants’ claims. Condemn the guilty party, declare the other innocent, and give both of them what they deserve.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If your people Israel are defeated by an enemy because they sinned against you, then if they come back to you, renew their allegiance to you, and pray for your help before you in this temple,
speaker: Narrator

text: then listen from heaven, forgive the sin of your people Israel, and bring them back to the land you gave to them and their ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The time will come when the skies are shut up tightly and no rain falls because your people sinned against you. When they direct their prayers toward this place, renew their allegiance to you, and turn away from their sin because you punish them,
speaker: Narrator

text: then listen from heaven and forgive the sin of your servants, your people Israel. Certainly you will then teach them the right way to live and send rain on your land that you have given your people to possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The time will come when the land suffers from a famine, a plague, blight, and disease, or a locust invasion, or when their enemy lays siege to the cities of the land, or when some other type of plague or epidemic occurs.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all your people Israel pray and ask for help, as they acknowledge their intense pain and spread out their hands toward this temple,
speaker: Narrator

text: then listen from your heavenly dwelling place, forgive their sin, and act favorably toward each one based on your evaluation of their motives. (Indeed you are the only one who can correctly evaluate the motives of all people.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they will honor you by obeying you throughout their lifetimes as they live on the land you gave to our ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Foreigners who do not belong to your people Israel will come from a distant land because of your great reputation and your ability to accomplish mighty deeds; they will come and direct their prayers toward this temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then listen from your heavenly dwelling place and answer all the prayers of the foreigners. Then all the nations of the earth will acknowledge your reputation, obey you as your people Israel do, and recognize that this temple I built belongs to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you direct your people to march out and fight their enemies, and they direct their prayers to you toward this chosen city and this temple I built for your honor,
speaker: Narrator

text: then listen from heaven to their prayers for help and vindicate them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The time will come when your people will sin against you (for there is no one who is sinless!) and you will be angry at them and deliver them over to their enemies, who will take them as prisoners to their land, whether far away or close by.
speaker: Narrator

text: When your people come to their senses in the land where they are held prisoner, they will repent and beg for your mercy in the land of their imprisonment, admitting, ‘We have sinned and gone astray, we have done evil!’
speaker: Narrator

text: When they return to you with all their heart and being in the land where they are held prisoner and direct their prayers toward the land you gave to their ancestors, your chosen city, and the temple I built for your honor,
speaker: Narrator

text: then listen from your heavenly dwelling place to their prayers for help, vindicate them, and forgive your sinful people.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now, my God, may you be attentive and responsive to the prayers offered in this place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now ascend, O Lord God, to your resting place, you and the ark of your strength! May your priests, O Lord God, experience your deliverance. May your loyal followers rejoice in the prosperity you give.
speaker: Narrator

text: O Lord God, do not reject your chosen ones! Remember the faithful promises you made to your servant David!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Solomon finished praying, fire came down from heaven and consumed the burnt offering and the sacrifices, and the Lord’s splendor filled the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests were unable to enter the Lord’s temple because the Lord’s splendor filled the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the Israelites saw the fire come down and the Lord’s splendor over the temple, they got on their knees with their faces downward toward the pavement. They worshiped and gave thanks to the Lord, saying, “Certainly he is good; certainly his loyal love endures!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king and all the people were presenting sacrifices to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon sacrificed 22,000 cattle and 120,000 sheep. Then the king and all the people dedicated God’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests stood in their assigned spots, along with the Levites who had the musical instruments used for praising the Lord. (These were the ones King David made for giving thanks to the Lord and which were used by David when he offered praise, saying, “Certainly his loyal love endures.”) Opposite the Levites, the priests were blowing the trumpets, while all Israel stood there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon consecrated the middle of the courtyard that is in front of the Lord’s temple. He offered burnt sacrifices, grain offerings, and the fat from the peace offerings there, because the bronze altar that Solomon had made was too small to hold all these offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Solomon and all Israel with him celebrated a festival for seven days. This great assembly included people from Lebo Hamath in the north to the Stream of Egypt in the south.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the eighth day they held an assembly, for they had dedicated the altar for seven days and celebrated the festival for seven more days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the twenty-third day of the seventh month, Solomon sent the people home. They left happy and contented because of the good the Lord had done for David, Solomon, and his people Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Solomon finished building the Lord’s temple and the royal palace and accomplished all his plans for the Lord’s temple and his royal palace,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Lord appeared to Solomon at night and said to him: “I have answered your prayer and chosen this place to be my temple where sacrifices are to be made.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I close up the sky so that it doesn’t rain, or command locusts to devour the land’s vegetation, or send a plague among my people,
speaker: Narrator

text: if my people, who belong to me, humble themselves, pray, seek to please me, and repudiate their sinful practices, then I will respond from heaven, forgive their sin, and heal their land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I will be attentive and responsive to the prayers offered in this place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I have chosen and consecrated this temple by making it my permanent home; I will be constantly present there.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must serve me as your father David did. Do everything I commanded and obey my rules and regulations.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I will establish your dynasty, just as I promised your father David, ‘You will not fail to have a successor ruling over Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But if you people ever turn away from me, fail to obey the regulations and rules I instructed you to keep, and decide to serve and worship other gods,
speaker: Narrator

text: then I will remove you from my land I have given you, I will abandon this temple I have consecrated with my presence, and I will make you an object of mockery and ridicule among all the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for this temple, which was once majestic, everyone who passes by it will be shocked and say, ‘Why did the Lord do this to this land and this temple?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Others will then answer, ‘Because they abandoned the Lord God of their ancestors, who led them out of Egypt. They embraced other gods whom they worshiped and served. That is why he brought all this disaster down on them.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: After twenty years, during which Solomon built the Lord’s temple and his royal palace,
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon rebuilt the cities that Huram had given him and settled Israelites there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon went to Hamath Zobah and seized it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He built up Tadmor in the wilderness and all the storage cities he had built in Hamath.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made upper Beth Horon and lower Beth Horon fortified cities with walls and barred gates,
speaker: Narrator

text: and built up Baalath, all the storage cities that belonged to him, and all the cities where chariots and horses were kept. He built whatever he wanted in Jerusalem, Lebanon, and throughout his entire kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now several non-Israelite peoples were left in the land after the conquest of Joshua, including the Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their descendants remained in the land (the Israelites were unable to wipe them out). Solomon conscripted them for his work crews, and they continue in that role to this very day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon did not assign Israelites to these work crews; the Israelites served as his soldiers, officers, charioteers, and commanders of his chariot forces.
speaker: Narrator

text: These men worked for King Solomon as supervisors; there were a total of 250 of them who were in charge of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon moved Pharaoh’s daughter up from the City of David to the palace he had built for her, for he said, “My wife must not live in the palace of King David of Israel, for the places where the ark of the Lord has entered are holy.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Solomon offered burnt sacrifices to the Lord on the altar of the Lord which he had built in front of the temple’s porch.
speaker: Narrator

text: He observed the daily requirements for sacrifices that Moses had specified for Sabbaths, new moon festivals, and the three annual celebrations—the Feast of Unleavened Bread, the Feast of Weeks, and the Feast of Shelters.
speaker: Narrator

text: As his father David had decreed, Solomon appointed the divisions of the priests to do their assigned tasks, the Levitical orders to lead worship and help the priests with their daily tasks, and the divisions of the gatekeepers to serve at their assigned gates. This was what David the man of God had ordered.
speaker: Narrator

text: They did not neglect any detail of the king’s orders pertaining to the priests, Levites, and treasuries.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the work ordered by Solomon was completed, from the day the foundation of the Lord’s temple was laid until it was finished; the Lord’s temple was completed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Solomon went to Ezion Geber and to Elat on the coast in the land of Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Huram sent him ships and some of his sailors, men who were well acquainted with the sea. They sailed with Solomon’s men to Ophir and took from there 450 talents of gold, which they brought back to King Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the queen of Sheba heard about Solomon, she came to challenge him with difficult questions. She arrived in Jerusalem with a great display of pomp, bringing with her camels carrying spices, a very large quantity of gold, and precious gems. She visited Solomon and discussed with him everything that was on her mind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon answered all her questions; there was no question too complex for the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the queen of Sheba saw for herself Solomon’s wisdom, the palace he had built,
speaker: Narrator

text: the food in his banquet hall, his servants and attendants in their robes, his cupbearers in their robes, and his burnt sacrifices which he presented in the Lord’s temple, she was amazed.
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to the king, “The report I heard in my own country about your wise sayings and insight was true!
speaker: Narrator

text: I did not believe these things until I came and saw them with my own eyes. Indeed, I didn’t hear even half the story! Your wisdom surpasses what was reported to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your attendants, who stand before you at all times and hear your wise sayings, are truly happy!
speaker: Narrator

text: May the Lord your God be praised because he favored you by placing you on his throne as the one ruling on his behalf. Because of your God’s love for Israel and his lasting commitment to them, he made you king over them so you could make just and right decisions.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She gave the king 120 talents of gold and a very large quantity of spices and precious gems. The quantity of spices the queen of Sheba gave King Solomon has never been matched.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Huram’s servants, aided by Solomon’s servants, brought gold from Ophir, as well as fine timber and precious gems.
speaker: Narrator

text: With the timber the king made steps for the Lord’s temple and royal palace as well as stringed instruments for the musicians. No one had seen anything like them in the land of Judah before that.)
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon gave the queen of Sheba everything she requested, more than what she had brought him. Then she left and returned to her homeland with her attendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon received 666 talents of gold per year,
speaker: Narrator

text: besides what he collected from the merchants and traders. All the Arabian kings and the governors of the land also brought gold and silver to Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon made 200 large shields of hammered gold; 600 measures of hammered gold were used for each shield.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also made 300 small shields of hammered gold; 300 measures of gold were used for each of those shields. The king placed them in the Palace of the Lebanon Forest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king made a large throne decorated with ivory and overlaid it with pure gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were six steps leading up to the throne, and a gold footstool was attached to the throne. The throne had two armrests with a statue of a lion standing on each side.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were twelve statues of lions on the six steps, one lion at each end of each step. There was nothing like it in any other kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of King Solomon’s cups were made of gold, and all the household items in the Palace of the Lebanon Forest were made of pure gold. There were no silver items, for silver was not considered very valuable in Solomon’s time.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king had a fleet of large merchant ships manned by Huram’s men that sailed the sea. Once every three years the fleet came into port with cargoes of gold, silver, ivory, apes, and peacocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon was wealthier and wiser than any of the kings of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the kings of the earth wanted to visit Solomon to see him display his God-given wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Year after year visitors brought their gifts, which included items of silver, items of gold, clothes, perfume, spices, horses, and mules.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon had 4,000 stalls for his chariot horses and 12,000 horses. He kept them in assigned cities and also with him in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He ruled all the kingdoms from the Euphrates River to the land of the Philistines as far as the border of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king made silver as plentiful in Jerusalem as stones; cedar was as plentiful as sycamore fig trees are in the foothills.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon acquired horses from Egypt and from all the lands.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events of Solomon’s reign, from start to finish, are recorded in the Annals of Nathan the Prophet, the Prophecy of Ahijah the Shilonite, and the Vision of Iddo the Seer pertaining to Jeroboam son of Nebat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon ruled over all Israel from Jerusalem for forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Solomon passed away and was buried in the city of his father David. His son Rehoboam replaced him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rehoboam traveled to Shechem, for all Israel had gathered in Shechem to make Rehoboam king.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jeroboam son of Nebat heard the news, he was still in Egypt, where he had fled from King Solomon. Jeroboam returned from Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: They sent for him, and Jeroboam and all Israel came and spoke to Rehoboam, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Your father made us work too hard! Now if you lighten the demands he made and don’t make us work as hard, we will serve you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “Go away for three days, then return to me.” So the people went away.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Rehoboam consulted with the older advisers who had served his father Solomon when he had been alive. He asked them, “How do you advise me to answer these people?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “If you are fair to these people, grant their request, and are cordial to them, they will be your servants from this time forward.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Rehoboam rejected their advice and consulted the young advisers who served him, with whom he had grown up.
speaker: Narrator

text: He asked them, “How do you advise me to respond to these people who said to me, ‘Lessen the demands your father placed on us’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The young advisers with whom Rehoboam had grown up said to him, “Say this to these people who have said to you, ‘Your father made us work hard, but now lighten our burden’—say this to them: ‘I am a lot harsher than my father!
speaker: Narrator

text: My father imposed heavy demands on you; I will make them even heavier. My father punished you with ordinary whips; I will punish you with whips that really sting your flesh.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam and all the people reported to Rehoboam on the third day, just as the king had ordered when he said, “Return to me on the third day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king responded to the people harshly. He rejected the advice of the older men
speaker: Narrator

text: and followed the advice of the younger ones. He said, “My father imposed heavy demands on you; I will make them even heavier. My father punished you with ordinary whips; I will punish you with whips that really sting your flesh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king refused to listen to the people, because God was instigating this turn of events so that he might bring to pass the prophetic announcement he had made through Ahijah the Shilonite to Jeroboam son of Nebat.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all Israel saw that the king refused to listen to them, the people answered the king, “We have no portion in David—no share in the son of Jesse! Return to your homes, O Israel! Now, look after your own dynasty, O David!” So all Israel returned to their homes.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Rehoboam continued to rule over the Israelites who lived in the cities of Judah.)
speaker: Narrator

text: King Rehoboam sent Hadoram, the supervisor of the work crews, out after them, but the Israelites stoned him to death. King Rehoboam managed to jump into his chariot and escape to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Israel has been in rebellion against the Davidic dynasty to this very day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Rehoboam arrived in Jerusalem, he summoned 180,000 skilled warriors from Judah and Benjamin to attack Israel and restore the kingdom to Rehoboam.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord’s message came to the prophet Shemaiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say this to King Rehoboam son of Solomon of Judah and to all the Israelites in Judah and Benjamin,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘The Lord says this: “Do not attack and make war with your brothers. Each of you go home, for I have caused this to happen.”’” They obeyed the Lord and called off the attack against Jeroboam.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rehoboam lived in Jerusalem; he built up these fortified cities throughout Judah:
speaker: Narrator

text: Bethlehem, Etam, Tekoa,
speaker: Narrator

text: Beth Zur, Soco, Adullam,
speaker: Narrator

text: Gath, Mareshah, Ziph,
speaker: Narrator

text: Adoraim, Lachish, Azekah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Zorah, Aijalon, and Hebron. These were the fortified cities in Judah and Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: He fortified these cities and placed officers in them, as well as storehouses of food, olive oil, and wine.
speaker: Narrator

text: In each city there were shields and spears; he strongly fortified them. Judah and Benjamin belonged to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests and Levites who lived throughout Israel supported him, no matter where they resided.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites even left their pasturelands and their property behind and came to Judah and Jerusalem, for Jeroboam and his sons prohibited them from serving as the Lord’s priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam appointed his own priests to serve at the worship centers and to lead in the worship of the goat idols and calf idols he had made.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those among all the Israelite tribes who were determined to worship the Lord God of Israel followed them to Jerusalem to sacrifice to the Lord God of their ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: They supported the kingdom of Judah and were loyal to Rehoboam son of Solomon for three years; they followed the edicts of David and Solomon for three years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rehoboam married Mahalath the daughter of David’s son Jerimoth and of Abihail, the daughter of Jesse’s son Eliab.
speaker: Narrator

text: She bore him sons named Jeush, Shemariah, and Zaham.
speaker: Narrator

text: He later married Maacah the daughter of Absalom. She bore to him Abijah, Attai, Ziza, and Shelomith.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rehoboam loved Maacah daughter of Absalom more than his other wives and concubines. He had eighteen wives and sixty concubines; he fathered twenty-eight sons and sixty daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rehoboam appointed Abijah son of Maacah as the leader over his brothers, for he intended to name him his successor.
speaker: Narrator

text: He wisely placed some of his many sons throughout the regions of Judah and Benjamin in the various fortified cities. He supplied them with abundant provisions and acquired many wives for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Rehoboam’s rule was established and solidified, he and all Israel rejected the law of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because they were unfaithful to the Lord, in King Rehoboam’s fifth year, King Shishak of Egypt attacked Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had 1,200 chariots, 60,000 horsemen, and an innumerable number of soldiers who accompanied him from Egypt, including Libyans, Sukkites, and Cushites.
speaker: Narrator

text: He captured the fortified cities of Judah and marched against Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shemaiah the prophet visited Rehoboam and the leaders of Judah who were assembled in Jerusalem because of Shishak. He said to them, “This is what the Lord says: ‘You have rejected me, so I have rejected you and will hand you over to Shishak.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The leaders of Israel and the king humbled themselves and said, “The Lord is just.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord saw that they humbled themselves, the Lord’s message came to Shemaiah: “They have humbled themselves, so I will not destroy them. I will deliver them soon. My anger will not be unleashed against Jerusalem through Shishak.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet they will become his subjects, so they can experience how serving me differs from serving the surrounding nations.”
speaker: Narrator

text: King Shishak of Egypt attacked Jerusalem and took away the treasures of the Lord’s temple and of the royal palace; he took everything, including the gold shields that Solomon had made.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Rehoboam made bronze shields to replace them and assigned them to the officers of the royal guard who protected the entrance to the royal palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever the king visited the Lord’s temple, the royal guards carried them and then brought them back to the guardroom.
speaker: Narrator

text: So when Rehoboam humbled himself, the Lord relented from his anger and did not annihilate him; Judah experienced some good things.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Rehoboam solidified his rule in Jerusalem; he was forty-one years old when he became king, and he ruled for seventeen years in Jerusalem, the city the Lord chose from all the tribes of Israel to be his home. Rehoboam’s mother was an Ammonite named Naamah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil because he was not determined to follow the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The events of Rehoboam’s reign, from start to finish, are recorded in the Annals of Shemaiah the Prophet and of Iddo the Seer that include genealogical records. There were wars between Rehoboam and Jeroboam continually.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rehoboam passed away and was buried in the City of David. His son Abijah replaced him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the eighteenth year of the reign of King Jeroboam, Abijah became king over Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He ruled for three years in Jerusalem. His mother was Michaiah, the daughter of Uriel from Gibeah.
There was war between Abijah and Jeroboam.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abijah launched the attack with 400,000 well-trained warriors, while Jeroboam deployed against him 800,000 well-trained warriors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abijah ascended Mount Zemaraim, in the Ephraimite hill country, and said: “Listen to me, Jeroboam and all Israel!
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t you realize that the Lord God of Israel has given David and his dynasty lasting dominion over Israel by a formal covenant?
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam son of Nebat, a servant of Solomon son of David, rose up and rebelled against his master.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lawless good-for-nothing men gathered around him and conspired against Rehoboam son of Solomon, when Rehoboam was an inexperienced young man and could not resist them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now you are declaring that you will resist the Lord’s rule through the Davidic dynasty. You have a huge army, and bring with you the gold calves that Jeroboam made for you as gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you banished the Lord’s priests, Aaron’s descendants, and the Levites, and appointed your own priests just as the surrounding nations do! Anyone who comes to consecrate himself with a young bull or seven rams becomes a priest of these fake gods!
speaker: Narrator

text: But as for us, the Lord is our God and we have not rejected him. Aaron’s descendants serve as the Lord’s priests, and the Levites assist them with the work.
speaker: Narrator

text: They offer burnt sacrifices to the Lord every morning and every evening, along with fragrant incense. They arrange the Bread of the Presence on a ritually clean table and light the lamps on the gold lampstand every evening. Certainly we are observing the Lord our God’s regulations, but you have rejected him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now look, God is with us as our leader. His priests are ready to blow the trumpets to signal the attack against you. You Israelites, don’t fight against the Lord God of your ancestors, for you will not win!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jeroboam had sent some men to ambush the Judahite army from behind. The main army was in front of the Judahite army; the ambushers were behind it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Judah turned around and realized they were being attacked from the front and the rear. So they cried out to the Lord for help. The priests blew their trumpets,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the men of Judah gave the battle cry. As the men of Judah gave the battle cry, God struck down Jeroboam and all Israel before Abijah and Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites fled from before the Judahite army, and God handed them over to the men of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abijah and his army thoroughly defeated them; 500,000 well-trained Israelite men fell dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: That day the Israelites were defeated; the men of Judah prevailed because they relied on the Lord God of their ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abijah chased Jeroboam; he seized from him these cities: Bethel and its surrounding towns, Jeshanah and its surrounding towns, and Ephron and its surrounding towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam did not regain power during the reign of Abijah. The Lord struck him down and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abijah’s power grew; he had fourteen wives and fathered twenty-two sons and sixteen daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events of Abijah’s reign, including his deeds and sayings, are recorded in the writings of the prophet Iddo.
speaker: Narrator

text: (13:23) Abijah passed away and was buried in the City of David. His son Asa replaced him as king. During his reign the land had rest for ten years.
speaker: Narrator

text: (14:1) Asa did what the Lord his God desired and approved.
speaker: Narrator

text: He removed the pagan altars and the high places, smashed the sacred pillars, and cut down the Asherah poles.
speaker: Narrator

text: He ordered Judah to seek the Lord God of their ancestors and to observe his law and commands.
speaker: Narrator

text: He removed the high places and the incense altars from all the towns of Judah. The kingdom had rest under his rule.
speaker: Narrator

text: He built fortified cities throughout Judah, for the land was at rest and there was no war during those years; the Lord gave him peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to the people of Judah: “Let’s build these cities and fortify them with walls, towers, and barred gates. The land remains ours because we have followed the Lord our God; we have followed him, and he has made us secure on all sides.” So they built the cities and prospered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Asa had an army of 300,000 men from Judah, equipped with large shields and spears. He also had 280,000 men from Benjamin who carried small shields and were adept archers; they were all skilled warriors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zerah the Cushite marched against them with an army of 1,000,000 men and 300 chariots . He arrived at Mareshah,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Asa went out to oppose him. They deployed for battle in the Valley of Zephathah near Mareshah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Asa prayed to the Lord his God: “O Lord, there is no one but you who can help the weak when they are vastly outnumbered. Help us, O Lord our God, for we rely on you and have marched on your behalf against this huge army. O Lord, you are our God; don’t let men prevail against you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord struck down the Cushites before Asa and Judah. The Cushites fled,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Asa and his army chased them as far as Gerar. The Cushites were wiped out; they were shattered before the Lord and his army. The men of Judah carried off a huge amount of plunder.
speaker: Narrator

text: They defeated all the towns surrounding Gerar, for the Lord caused them to panic. The men of Judah looted all the towns, for they contained a huge amount of goods.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also attacked the tents of the herdsmen in charge of the livestock. They carried off many sheep and camels and then returned to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: God’s Spirit came upon Azariah son of Oded.
speaker: Narrator

text: He met Asa and told him, “Listen to me, Asa and all Judah and Benjamin! The Lord is with you when you are loyal to him. If you seek him, he will respond to you, but if you reject him, he will reject you.
speaker: Narrator

text: For a long time Israel had not sought the one true God, or a priest to instruct them, or the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of their distress, they turned back to the Lord God of Israel. They sought him and he responded to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days no one could travel safely, for total chaos had overtaken all the people of the surrounding lands.
speaker: Narrator

text: One nation was crushed by another, and one city by another, for God caused them to be in great turmoil.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as for you, be strong and don’t get discouraged, for your work will be rewarded.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Asa heard these words and the prophecy of Oded the prophet, he was encouraged. He removed the detestable idols from the entire land of Judah and Benjamin and from the cities he had seized in the Ephraimite hill country. He repaired the altar of the Lord in front of the porch of the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: He assembled all Judah and Benjamin, as well as the settlers from Ephraim, Manasseh, and Simeon who had come to live with them. Many people from Israel had come there to live when they saw that the Lord his God was with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They assembled in Jerusalem in the third month of the fifteenth year of Asa’s reign.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time they sacrificed to the Lord some of the plunder they had brought back, including 700 head of cattle and 7,000 sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: They solemnly agreed to seek the Lord God of their ancestors with their whole heart and being.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who would not seek the Lord God of Israel would be executed, whether they were young or old, male or female.
speaker: Narrator

text: They swore their allegiance to the Lord, shouting their approval loudly and sounding trumpets and horns.
speaker: Narrator

text: All Judah was happy about the oath, because they made the vow with their whole heart. They willingly sought the Lord and he responded to them. He made them secure on every side.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Asa also removed Maacah his grandmother from her position as queen mother because she had made a loathsome Asherah pole. Asa cut down her loathsome pole and crushed and burned it in the Kidron Valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: The high places were not eliminated from Israel, yet Asa was wholeheartedly devoted to the Lord throughout his lifetime.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought the holy items that his father and he had made into God’s temple, including the silver, gold, and other articles.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was no more war until the thirty-fifth year of Asa’s reign.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the thirty-sixth year of Asa’s reign, King Baasha of Israel attacked Judah, and he established Ramah as a military outpost to prevent anyone from leaving or entering the land of King Asa of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Asa took all the silver and gold that was left in the treasuries of the Lord’s temple and of the royal palace and sent it to King Ben Hadad of Syria, ruler in Damascus, along with this message:
speaker: Narrator

text: “I want to make a treaty with you, like the one our fathers made. See, I have sent you silver and gold. Break your treaty with King Baasha of Israel, so he will retreat from my land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ben Hadad accepted King Asa’s offer and ordered his army commanders to attack the cities of Israel. They conquered Ijon, Dan, Abel Maim, and all the storage cities of Naphtali.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Baasha heard the news, he stopped fortifying Ramah and abandoned the project.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Asa ordered all the men of Judah to carry away the stones and wood that Baasha had used to build Ramah. He used the materials to build up Geba and Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Hanani the prophet visited King Asa of Judah and said to him: “Because you relied on the king of Syria and did not rely on the Lord your God, the army of the king of Syria has escaped from your hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Did not the Cushites and Libyans have a huge army with chariots and a very large number of horsemen? But when you relied on the Lord, he handed them over to you!
speaker: Narrator

text: Certainly the Lord watches the whole earth carefully and is ready to strengthen those who are devoted to him. You have acted foolishly in this matter; from now on you will have war.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Asa was so angry at the prophet, he put him in jail. Asa also oppressed some of the people at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: The events of Asa’s reign, from start to finish, are recorded in the Scroll of the Kings of Judah and Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the thirty-ninth year of his reign, Asa developed a foot disease and his disease became severe. Yet even in his disease, he did not seek the Lord, but only the doctors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Asa passed away in the forty-first year of his reign.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was buried in the tomb he had carved out in the City of David. They laid him to rest on a platform covered with spices and assorted mixtures of ointments. They made a huge bonfire to honor him.
speaker: Narrator

text: His son Jehoshaphat replaced him as king and solidified his rule over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He placed troops in all Judah’s fortified cities and posted garrisons throughout the land of Judah and in the cities of Ephraim that his father Asa had seized.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord was with Jehoshaphat because he followed in his ancestor David’s footsteps at the beginning of his reign. He did not seek the Baals,
speaker: Narrator

text: but instead sought the God of his ancestors and obeyed his commands, unlike the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord made his kingdom secure; all Judah brought tribute to Jehoshaphat, and he became very wealthy and greatly respected.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was committed to following the Lord; he even removed the high places and Asherah poles from Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the third year of his reign he sent his officials Ben Hail, Obadiah, Zechariah, Nethanel, and Micaiah to teach in the cities of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were accompanied by the Levites Shemaiah, Nethaniah, Zebadiah, Asahel, Shemiramoth, Jehonathan, Adonijah, Tobijah, and Tob-Adonijah, and by the priests Elishama and Jehoram.
speaker: Narrator

text: They taught throughout Judah, taking with them the scroll of the law of the Lord. They traveled to all the cities of Judah and taught the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord put fear into all the kingdoms surrounding Judah; they did not make war with Jehoshaphat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the Philistines brought Jehoshaphat tribute, including a load of silver. The Arabs brought him 7,700 rams and 7,700 goats from their flocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat’s power kept increasing. He built fortresses and storage cities throughout Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had many supplies stored in the cities of Judah and an army of skilled warriors stationed in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These were their divisions by families:
There were 1,000 officers from Judah. Adnah the commander led 300,000 skilled warriors,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehochanan the commander led 280,000,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Amasiah son of Zikri, who volunteered to serve the Lord, led 200,000 skilled warriors.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Benjamin, Eliada, a skilled warrior, led 200,000 men who were equipped with bows and shields,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Jehozabad led 180,000 trained warriors.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the ones who served the king, besides those whom the king placed in the fortified cities throughout Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat was very wealthy and greatly respected. He made an alliance by marriage with Ahab,
speaker: Narrator

text: and after several years went down to visit Ahab in Samaria. Ahab slaughtered many sheep and cattle to honor Jehoshaphat and those who came with him. He persuaded him to join in an attack against Ramoth Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Ahab of Israel said to King Jehoshaphat of Judah, “Will you go with me to attack Ramoth Gilead?” He replied, “I will support you; my army is at your disposal and will support you in battle.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehoshaphat said further to the king of Israel, “First, please seek an oracle from the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king of Israel assembled 400 prophets and asked them, “Should we attack Ramoth Gilead or not?” They said, “Attack! God will hand it over to the king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jehoshaphat asked, “Is there not a prophet of the Lord still here, that we may ask him?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel answered Jehoshaphat, “There is still one man through whom we can seek the Lord’s will, but I despise him because he does not prophesy prosperity for me, but always disaster—Micaiah son of Imlah.” Jehoshaphat said, “The king should not say such things!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel summoned an officer and said, “Quickly bring Micaiah son of Imlah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the king of Israel and King Jehoshaphat of Judah were sitting on their respective thrones, dressed in their royal robes, at the threshing floor at the entrance of the gate of Samaria. All the prophets were prophesying before them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zedekiah son of Kenaanah made iron horns and said, “This is what the Lord says, ‘With these you will gore Syria until they are destroyed.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: All the prophets were prophesying the same, saying, “Attack Ramoth Gilead! You will succeed; the Lord will hand it over to the king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the messenger who went to summon Micaiah said to him, “Look, the prophets are in complete agreement that the king will succeed. Your words must agree with theirs; you must predict success!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Micaiah said, “As certainly as the Lord lives, I will say what my God tells me to say!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Micaiah came before the king and the king asked him, “Micaiah, should we attack Ramoth Gilead or not?” He answered him, “Attack! You will succeed; they will be handed over to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to him, “How many times must I make you solemnly promise in the name of the Lord to tell me only the truth?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Micaiah replied, “I saw all Israel scattered on the mountains like sheep that have no shepherd. Then the Lord said, ‘They have no master. They should go home in peace.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, “Didn’t I tell you he does not prophesy prosperity for me, but disaster?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Micaiah said, “That being the case, listen to the Lord’s message. I saw the Lord sitting on his throne, with all the heavenly assembly standing on his right and on his left.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said, ‘Who will deceive King Ahab of Israel, so he will attack Ramoth Gilead and die there?’ One said this and another that.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a spirit stepped forward and stood before the Lord. He said, ‘I will deceive him.’ The Lord asked him, ‘How?’
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, ‘I will go out and be a lying spirit in the mouths of all his prophets.’ The Lord said, ‘Deceive and overpower him. Go out and do as you have proposed.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, look, the Lord has placed a lying spirit in the mouths of all these prophets of yours, but the Lord has decreed disaster for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Zedekiah son of Kenaanah approached, hit Micaiah on the jaw, and said, “Which way did the Lord’s Spirit go when he went from me to speak to you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Micaiah replied, “Look, you will see in the day when you go into an inner room to hide.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Israel said, “Take Micaiah and return him to Amon the city official and Joash the king’s son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say, ‘This is what the king says: “Put this man in prison. Give him only a little bread and water until I return safely.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Micaiah said, “If you really do return safely, then the Lord has not spoken through me!” Then he added, “Take note, all you people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel and King Jehoshaphat of Judah attacked Ramoth Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, “I will disguise myself and then enter the battle, but you wear your royal attire.” So the king of Israel disguised himself and they entered the battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the king of Syria had ordered his chariot commanders, “Do not fight common soldiers or high ranking officers; fight only the king of Israel!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the chariot commanders saw Jehoshaphat, they said, “He must be the king of Israel!” So they turned and attacked him, but Jehoshaphat cried out. The Lord helped him; God lured them away from him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the chariot commanders realized he was not the king of Israel, they turned away from him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now an archer shot an arrow at random, and it struck the king of Israel between the plates of his armor. The king ordered his charioteer, “Turn around and take me from the battle line, for I am wounded.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While the battle raged throughout the day, the king of Israel stood propped up in his chariot opposite the Syrians. He died in the evening as the sun was setting.
speaker: Narrator

text: When King Jehoshaphat of Judah returned home safely to Jerusalem,
speaker: Narrator

text: the prophet Jehu son of Hanani confronted him; he said to King Jehoshaphat, “Is it right to help the wicked and be an ally of those who oppose the Lord? Because you have done this, the Lord is angry with you!
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless you have done some good things; you removed the Asherah poles from the land and you were determined to follow God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat lived in Jerusalem. He went out among the people from Beer Sheba to the hill country of Ephraim and encouraged them to follow the Lord God of their ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: He appointed judges throughout the land and in each of the fortified cities of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told the judges, “Be careful what you do, for you are not judging for men, but for the Lord, who will be with you when you make judicial decisions.
speaker: Narrator

text: Respect the Lord and make careful decisions, for the Lord our God disapproves of injustice, partiality, and bribery.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In Jerusalem Jehoshaphat appointed some Levites, priests, and Israelite family leaders to judge on behalf of the Lord and to settle disputes among the residents of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He commanded them: “Carry out your duties with respect for the Lord, with honesty, and with pure motives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever your countrymen who live in the cities bring a case before you (whether it involves a violent crime or other matters related to the law, commandments, rules, and regulations), warn them that they must not sin against the Lord. If you fail to do so, God will be angry with you and your colleagues, but if you obey, you will be free of guilt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take note, Amariah the chief priest will oversee you in every matter pertaining to the Lord and Zebadiah son of Ishmael, the leader of the family of Judah, in every matter pertaining to the king. The Levites will serve as officials before you. Act courageously, and may the Lord be with those who do well!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Later the Moabites and Ammonites, along with some of the Meunites, attacked Jehoshaphat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Messengers arrived and reported to Jehoshaphat, “A huge army is attacking you from the other side of the Dead Sea, from the direction of Edom. Look, they are in Hazazon Tamar (that is, En Gedi).”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat was afraid, so he decided to seek the Lord’s advice. He decreed that all Judah should observe a fast.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Judah assembled to ask for the Lord’s help; they came from all the cities of Judah to ask for the Lord’s help.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat stood before the assembly of Judah and Jerusalem at the Lord’s temple, in front of the new courtyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: He prayed: “O Lord God of our ancestors, you are the God who lives in heaven and rules over all the kingdoms of the nations. You possess strength and power; no one can stand against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our God, you drove out the inhabitants of this land before your people Israel and gave it as a permanent possession to the descendants of your friend Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: They settled down in it and built in it a temple to honor you, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘If disaster comes on us in the form of military attack, judgment, plague, or famine, we will stand in front of this temple before you, for you are present in this temple. We will cry out to you for help in our distress, so that you will hear and deliver us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Ammonites, Moabites, and men from Mount Seir are coming! When Israel came from the land of Egypt, you did not allow them to invade these lands. They bypassed them and did not destroy them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look how they are repaying us! They come to drive us out of our allotted land which you assigned to us!
speaker: Narrator

text: Our God, will you not judge them? For we are powerless against this huge army that attacks us. We don’t know what we should do; we look to you for help.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All the men of Judah were standing before the Lord, along with their infants, wives, and children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then in the midst of the assembly, the Lord’s Spirit came upon Jachaziel son of Zechariah, son of Benaiah, son of Jeiel, son of Mattaniah, a Levite and descendant of Asaph.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said: “Pay attention, all you people of Judah, residents of Jerusalem, and King Jehoshaphat! This is what the Lord says to you: ‘Don’t be afraid and don’t panic because of this huge army! For the battle is not yours, but God’s.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tomorrow march down against them as they come up the Ascent of Ziz. You will find them at the end of the ravine in front of the wilderness of Jeruel.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will not fight in this battle. Take your positions, stand, and watch the Lord deliver you, O Judah and Jerusalem. Don’t be afraid and don’t panic! Tomorrow march out toward them; the Lord is with you!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat bowed down with his face toward the ground, and all the people of Judah and the residents of Jerusalem fell down before the Lord and worshiped him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then some Levites, from the Kohathites and Korahites, got up and loudly praised the Lord God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Early the next morning they marched out to the wilderness of Tekoa. When they were ready to march, Jehoshaphat stood up and said: “Listen to me, you people of Judah and residents of Jerusalem! Trust in the Lord your God and you will be safe! Trust in the message of his prophets and you will win.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He met with the people and appointed musicians to play before the Lord and praise his majestic splendor. As they marched ahead of the warriors they said: “Give thanks to the Lord, for his loyal love endures.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they began to shout and praise, the Lord suddenly attacked the Ammonites, Moabites, and men from Mount Seir who were invading Judah, and they were defeated.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Ammonites and Moabites attacked the men from Mount Seir and annihilated them. When they had finished off the men of Seir, they attacked and destroyed one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men of Judah arrived at the observation post overlooking the wilderness and looked at the huge army, they saw dead bodies on the ground; there were no survivors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat and his men went to gather the plunder; they found a huge amount of supplies, clothing, and valuable items. They carried away everything they could. There was so much plunder, it took them three days to haul it off.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the fourth day they assembled in the Valley of Berachah, where they praised the Lord. So that place is called the Valley of Berachah to this very day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the men of Judah and Jerusalem returned joyfully to Jerusalem with Jehoshaphat leading them; the Lord had given them reason to rejoice over their enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: They entered Jerusalem to the sound of stringed instruments and trumpets and proceeded to the temple of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the kingdoms of the surrounding lands were afraid of God when they heard how the Lord had fought against Israel’s enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat’s kingdom enjoyed peace; his God made him secure on every side.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat reigned over Judah. He was thirty-five years old when he became king and he reigned for twenty-five years in Jerusalem. His mother was Azubah, the daughter of Shilhi.
speaker: Narrator

text: He followed in his father Asa’s footsteps and was careful to do what the Lord approved.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, the high places were not eliminated; the people were still not devoted to the God of their ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events of Jehoshaphat’s reign, from start to finish, are recorded in the Annals of Jehu son of Hanani, which are included in the Scroll of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later King Jehoshaphat of Judah made an alliance with King Ahaziah of Israel, who did evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: They agreed to make large seagoing merchant ships; they built the ships in Ezion Geber.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eliezer son of Dodavahu from Mareshah prophesied against Jehoshaphat, “Because you made an alliance with Ahaziah, the Lord will shatter what you have made.” The ships were wrecked and unable to go to sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat passed away and was buried with his ancestors in the City of David. His son Jehoram replaced him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: His brothers, Jehoshaphat’s sons, were Azariah, Jechiel, Zechariah, Azariahu, Michael, and Shephatiah. All these were sons of King Jehoshaphat of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their father gave them many presents, including silver, gold, and other precious items, along with fortified cities in Judah. But he gave the kingdom to Jehoram because he was the firstborn.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoram took control of his father’s kingdom and became powerful. Then he killed all his brothers, as well as some of the officials of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoram was thirty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned for eight years in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He followed in the footsteps of the kings of Israel, just as Ahab’s dynasty had done, for he married Ahab’s daughter. He did evil in the sight of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord was unwilling to destroy David’s dynasty because of the promise he had made to give David a perpetual dynasty.
speaker: Narrator

text: During Jehoram’s reign Edom freed themselves from Judah’s control and set up their own king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoram crossed over with his officers and all his chariots. The Edomites, who had surrounded him, attacked at night and defeated him and his chariot officers.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Edom has remained free from Judah’s control to this very day. At that same time Libnah also rebelled and freed themselves from Judah’s control because Jehoram rejected the Lord God of his ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also built high places on the hills of Judah; he encouraged the residents of Jerusalem to be unfaithful to the Lord and led Judah away from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoram received this letter from Elijah the prophet: “This is what the Lord God of your ancestor David says: ‘You have not followed in the footsteps of your father Jehoshaphat and of King Asa of Judah,
speaker: Narrator

text: but have instead followed in the footsteps of the kings of Israel. You encouraged the people of Judah and the residents of Jerusalem to be unfaithful to the Lord, just as the family of Ahab does in Israel. You also killed your brothers, members of your father’s family, who were better than you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So look, the Lord is about to severely afflict your people, your sons, your wives, and all you own.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you will get a serious, chronic intestinal disease which will cause your intestines to come out.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord stirred up against Jehoram the Philistines and the Arabs who lived beside the Cushites.
speaker: Narrator

text: They attacked Judah and swept through it. They carried off everything they found in the royal palace, including his sons and wives. None of his sons was left, except for his youngest, Ahaziah.
speaker: Narrator

text: After all this happened, the Lord afflicted him with an incurable intestinal disease.
speaker: Narrator

text: After about two years his intestines came out because of the disease, so that he died a very painful death. His people did not make a bonfire to honor him, as they had done for his ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoram was thirty-two years old when he became king and he reigned eight years in Jerusalem. No one regretted his death; he was buried in the City of David, but not in the royal tombs.
speaker: Narrator

text: The residents of Jerusalem made his youngest son Ahaziah king in his place, for the raiding party that invaded the camp with the Arabs had killed all the older sons. So Ahaziah son of Jehoram became king of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaziah was twenty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned for one year in Jerusalem. His mother was Athaliah, the granddaughter of Omri.
speaker: Narrator

text: He followed in the footsteps of Ahab’s dynasty, for his mother gave him evil advice.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord like Ahab’s dynasty because, after his father’s death, they gave him advice that led to his destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text: He followed their advice and joined Ahab’s son King Joram of Israel in a battle against King Hazael of Syria at Ramoth Gilead in which the Syrians defeated Joram.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joram returned to Jezreel to recover from the wounds he received from the Syrians in Ramah when he fought against King Hazael of Syria. Ahaziah son of King Jehoram of Judah went down to visit Joram son of Ahab in Jezreel, because he had been wounded.
speaker: Narrator

text: God brought about Ahaziah’s downfall through his visit to Joram. When Ahaziah arrived, he went out with Joram to meet Jehu son of Nimshi, whom the Lord had commissioned to wipe out Ahab’s family.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Jehu was dishing out punishment to Ahab’s family, he discovered the officials of Judah and the sons of Ahaziah’s relatives who were serving Ahaziah and killed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He looked for Ahaziah, who was captured while hiding in Samaria. They brought him to Jehu and then executed him. They did give him a burial, for they reasoned, “He is the son of Jehoshaphat, who sought the Lord with his whole heart.” There was no one in Ahaziah’s family strong enough to rule in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Athaliah the mother of Ahaziah saw that her son was dead, she was determined to destroy the entire royal line of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehoshabeath, the daughter of King Jehoram, took Ahaziah’s son Joash and stole him away from the rest of the royal descendants who were to be executed. She hid him and his nurse in the room where the bed covers were stored. So Jehoshabeath the daughter of King Jehoram, wife of Jehoiada the priest and sister of Ahaziah, hid him from Athaliah so she could not execute him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He remained in hiding in God’s temple for six years while Athaliah was ruling over the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the seventh year Jehoiada made a bold move. He made a pact with the officers of the units of hundreds: Azariah son of Jehoram, Ishmael son of Jehochanan, Azariah son of Obed, Maaseiah son of Adaiah, and Elishaphat son of Zikri.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They traveled throughout Judah and assembled the Levites from all the cities of Judah, as well as the Israelite family leaders.
They came to Jerusalem,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the whole assembly made a covenant with the king in the temple of God. Jehoiada said to them, “The king’s son will rule, just as the Lord promised David’s descendants.
speaker: Narrator
